DCS World – Almost like flying for real (especially in VR)

I really enjoy this game, and I play it almost exclusively in VR. The realism is impeccable — it feels almost lifelike. The aircraft systems and flight models are incredibly detailed, and learning how each plane works is a big part of the fun.

It’s not impossible to get into, but it’s definitely a challenge — the perfect mix for anyone who enjoys learning and mastering complex systems. Carrier operations are particularly impressive and realistic, and there’s nothing quite like the feeling of catching the wire after a smooth landing.

I also love creating my own missions and flying those made by other players. The online experience can be amazing too, especially when you find players who simulate ATC or coordinate as a proper flight group. When that happens, it feels like a full-on military sim experience.

DCS World is a brilliant mix of realism, creativity, and community — if you’ve got the hardware and patience, it’s absolutely worth diving into.

In it's current state, and with the recent behavior and actions of the developers, not only can I not recommend this game, but I implore all users to not play this game for the foreseeable future. 

DCS World is a game by a developer that does not know how to make games. This much they have admitted openly. Eagle Dynamics also, very evidently so, does not have any plan for the future of the game, beyond simply putting out modules that they believe will sell in high quantities. They routinely release modules in such an empty state that it is egregious even for early access products, and abandon them after release for months, breaking promises on when updates will come as regularly as they breathe. They have a habit of promising new modules and features, and releasing them in the most half-baked manner possible, then promising that updates will come to those modules and features to flesh them out, and those updates never arrive, leaving practically every feature and mechanic in the game in a perpetually half-finished state.

Eagle Dynamics is only motivated by money. If given the opportunity, they have proven that they will screw over not only their customers, but also the 3rd party developers who build modules for this game, all of which are near-universally superior to any of ED's own modules. They will lie, mislead, exaggerate, and gaslight their consumers in order to trick them into spending more money on their products. 

Here are just a few examples of incidents within the last 2 years:

Afghanistan map - This map was released in an early access state that was so barren and unfinished it was unbelievable. The map was split into thirds, and only one third was made available at launch. Map textures were obnoxiously lazy, and building assets were copy-pasted from other maps, and did not fit the area being simulated whatsoever. Updates were promised within 3 months, including the release of the other parts of the map. It released in June of 2024 and took over a year for basic updates to come to the map, and so far as of October of 2025, none of the other portions of the map have been released. We have no timeline on when the other portions will actually make to the game, other than what was promised on launch, which was then quickly abandoned.

F-5E "Remaster": One of the oldest modules in the game, and one with a number of technical issues, and easily provable inaccuracies in its systems simulations and one of the most broken and least accurate flight models in the game was slated for a remaster in Fall of 2024. It promised bug fixes, a new external model, and a "rebuilt from scratch" cockpit. However, once the remaster released, the legacy F-5 module would no longer receive any updates. You would have to purchase the remaster in order to insure that your F-5 would continue to receive updates, and eventually the legacy F-5 would no longer be playable, though no timeline on when that would happen was announced. 

The only problem is that the most glaring issues with the F-5 module were not addressed at all. Many of the existing bugs still persist, including its terrible flight model. The new external model it received rendered 8 years of community liveries unusable, and offered very few vanilla liveries of its own. To make matters worse, the external model files were encrypted, making it exceedingly difficult to make new liveries for the module. Worse still, when the model files were ripped to help make liveries, it was discovered that the "built from scratch" cockpit was actually the same cockpit as the original module, which had just received a polish and a higher polygon count, which also had the effect of lowering frame rates while flying it. 

ED lied about the cockpit being brand new, and encrypted the files to try and ensure that nobody would be able to find out. And the cherry on the cake is that once you purchased the remaster, it permanently overwrote the legacy F-5 module, so players would not be able to revert to the original. In short, players paid $15 to essentially downgrade their F-5 module just to ensure it would continue working in the future. When criticized for the obvious misdirection and anti-consumer behavior, ED's community managers simply replied that "the remaster had sold well" and thus that ED had nothing to apologize for.

Flaming Cliffs 2024: In short, ED took 3 existing "full fidelity" modules, the F-5E, the F-86, and the MiG-15, and downgraded them into low-fidelity modules, in the process removing important capabilities and features of those modules, and resold them as new modules. I have few other words except that it was a blatant and shameless cash grab. 

Razbam: Razbam was a major third party developer for DCS, releasing some of the most important modules for the game, including the MiG-19, Mirage 2000, AV-8B Harrier, and F-15E Strike Eagle. About a year after the F-15Es release, it became clear that ED had been withholding pay from Razbam owed to them via the F-15Es sales. Recently a leaked Zoom call showing this situation being discussed between the CEO of ED, Nick Grey, and the CEO of Razbam, Ron Zambrano. 

During the call, Nick Grey repeatedly tells Ron that he is deliberately withholding pay owed to Razbam as leverage(Nick Grey's actual words) to strongarm Razbam into signing an unrelated contract for MCS, the commercial side of DCS, used for government contracts. ED had spent the year since this call alleging that Razbam had committed some kind of IP violation by developing an MCS module without authorization, but the Zoom call made it clear that this was not possible, because Razbam did not have the SDKs to work on MCS, and the only thing ever made for this hypothetical project was a basic 3d model. The validity of this call was verified by ED's own community managers. 

Now, as a result of this blatant illegal violation of contract law on the part of ED, Razbam's modules were removed from sale, and they will no longer be playable in DCS upon the release of v3.0.

These are all just examples of anti-consumer behavior, which is bad enough, but the game itself is in a very poor state, and it is heavily divided. 

This is difficult for people to accept or realize, but compared to hardcore sim contemporaries like Falcon BMS, even loose contemporaries such as War Thunder, DCS has some of the weakest systems modeling and fidelity in the genre. Systems like Radar, missile seeker heads, countermeasures, missile kinematic performance, clouds modeling, FLIR, and other critically important mechanics are objectively simulated to a less rigorous degree than either Falcon BMS or War Thunder, despite DCS promising a genre-peak simulation fidelity.

Furthermore, because of how long DCS has been around, and how many different developers have made modules for it, there is little to no consistent standard between modules. Many modules are simulated to a higher or lower degree of accuracy and fidelity, and quite often, modules which are simulated to a poor standard end up providing a material advantage during gameplay. For instance, many ED modules, or modules such as the MiG-21 and Mirage F1, have very poor radar simulation. The radar simulation is so basic, that those radars often do not have their historical disadvantages and downsides simulated, so they drastically overperform. 

There is honestly so much more I could say, but I've been writing this for literally hours at this point. The iceberg goes extremely deep. I had to cut over 2000 characters just for this review to pass the maximum character count. Eagle Dynamics and DCS is an absolute mess, and I cannot warn you in any stronger terms to never, EVER, spend any money on this game. This game is mechanically barren and a broken mess at the best of days. Avoid at all costs.

DCS World Steam Edition is less a game and more a military grade training simulator with a free hangar door, but every actual plane inside comes with a price tag that makes you feel like you’re funding your own private air force. Sure, the fidelity is jaw dropping, every switch, gauge, and knob rendered with obsessive precision but the cost borders on absurd, with single aircraft modules going for the price of full AAA releases and maps stacked on top like you’re building an $800 Lego set. Add in the steepest learning curve imaginable, where you’re just as likely to crash your jet as you are your wallet, and it becomes clear this is less about flying for fun and more about committing to a luxury hobby. It’s impressive from a distance, but up close you realise you’re not playing a flight sim, you’re signing up for the digital equivalent of a defense contractor’s subscription plan, a bottomless money pit disguised as a cockpit.

It is not ethical to buy anything from them after the leaked Zoom call. 
Other than that, the future of DCS is a big question. The current state of the game is really bad, and I see no hope for it to improve....

Updates were promised within 3 months, including the release of the other parts of the map. It released in June of 2024 and took over a year for basic updates to come to the map, and so far as of October of 2025, none of the other portions of the map have been released. We have no timeline on when the other portions will actually make to the game, other than what was promised on launch, which was then quickly abandoned.

F-5E "Remaster": One of the oldest modules in the game, and one with a number of technical issues, and easily provable inaccuracies in its systems simulations and one of the most broken and least accurate flight models in the game was slated for a remaster in Fall of 2024. It promised bug fixes, a new external model, and a "rebuilt from scratch" cockpit. However, once the remaster released, the legacy F-5 module would no longer receive any updates. You would have to purchase the remaster in order to insure that your F-5 would continue to receive updates, and eventually the legacy F-5 would no longer be playable, though no timeline on when that would happen was announced. 

The only problem is that the most glaring issues with the F-5 module were not addressed at all. Many of the existing bugs still persist, including its terrible flight model. The new external model it received rendered 8 years of community liveries unusable, and offered very few vanilla liveries of its own. To make matters worse, the external model files were encrypted, making it exceedingly difficult to make new liveries for the module. Worse still, when the model files were ripped to help make liveries, it was discovered that the "built from scratch" cockpit was actually the same cockpit as the original module, which had just received a polish and a higher polygon count, which also had the effect of lowering frame rates while flying it. 

ED lied about the cockpit being brand new, and encrypted the files to try and ensure that nobody would be able to find out. And the cherry on the cake is that once you purchased the remaster, it permanently overwrote the legacy F-5 module, so players would not be able to revert to the original. In short, players paid $15 to essentially downgrade their F-5 module just to ensure it would continue working in the future. When criticized for the obvious misdirection and anti-consumer behavior, ED's community managers simply replied that "the remaster had sold well" and thus that ED had nothing to apologize for.

Flaming Cliffs 2024: In short, ED took 3 existing "full fidelity" modules, the F-5E, the F-86, and the MiG-15, and downgraded them into low-fidelity modules, in the process removing important capabilities and features of those modules, and resold them as new modules. I have few other words except that it was a blatant and shameless cash grab. 

Razbam: Razbam was a major third party developer for DCS, releasing some of the most important modules for the game, including the MiG-19, Mirage 2000, AV-8B Harrier, and F-15E Strike Eagle. About a year after the F-15Es release, it became clear that ED had been withholding pay from Razbam owed to them via the F-15Es sales. Recently a leaked Zoom call showing this situation being discussed between the CEO of ED, Nick Grey, and the CEO of Razbam, Ron Zambrano. 

During the call, Nick Grey repeatedly tells Ron that he is deliberately withholding pay owed to Razbam as leverage(Nick Grey's actual words) to strongarm Razbam into signing an unrelated contract for MCS, the commercial side of DCS, used for government contracts. ED had spent the year since this call alleging that Razbam had committed some kind of IP violation by developing an MCS module without authorization, but the Zoom call made it clear that this was not possible, because Razbam did not have the SDKs to work on MCS, and the only thing ever made for this hypothetical project was a basic 3d model. The validity of this call was verified by ED's own community managers. 

Now, as a result of this blatant illegal violation of contract law on the part of ED, Razbam's modules were removed from sale, and they will no longer be playable in DCS upon the release of v3.0.

These are all just examples of anti-consumer behavior, which is bad enough, but the game itself is in a very poor state, and it is heavily divided. 

This is difficult for people to accept or realize, but compared to hardcore sim contemporaries like Falcon BMS, even loose contemporaries such as War Thunder, DCS has some of the weakest systems modeling and fidelity in the genre. Systems like Radar, missile seeker heads, countermeasures, missile kinematic performance, clouds modeling, FLIR, and other critically important mechanics are objectively simulated to a less rigorous degree than either Falcon BMS or War Thunder, despite DCS promising a genre-peak simulation fidelity.

Furthermore, because of how long DCS has been around, and how many different developers have made modules for it, there is little to no consistent standard between modules. Many modules are simulated to a higher or lower degree of accuracy and fidelity, and quite often, modules which are simulated to a poor standard end up providing a material advantage during gameplay. For instance, many ED modules, or modules such as the MiG-21 and Mirage F1, have very poor radar simulation. The radar simulation is so basic, that those radars often do not have their historical disadvantages and downsides simulated, so they drastically overperform. 

There is honestly so much more I could say, but I've been writing this for literally hours at this point. The iceberg goes extremely deep. I had to cut over 2000 characters just for this review to pass the maximum character count. Eagle Dynamics and DCS is an absolute mess, and I cannot warn you in any stronger terms to never, EVER, spend any money on this game. This game is mechanically barren and a broken mess at the best of days. Avoid at all costs.
